title: 106_s2424
content: The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" allows for a credit for low-income individuals to purchase computers under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" provides a tax credit for eligible individuals equal to 50% of the amount spent on qualified computer technology or equipment, up to a maximum of $500 per year. Eligible individuals are those who qualify for the earned income credit. Qualified computer technology or equipment refers to items defined in section 170(e)(6). The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" offers a tax credit for eligible individuals for purchasing qualified computer technology or equipment. Exceptions include game software and computers without internet access capabilities. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" offers a tax credit for eligible individuals for purchasing qualified computer technology or equipment. Amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of such Code. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" provides tax credits for purchasing computers by low-income individuals and extends the deduction for charitable contributions of computers. Effective date for amendments is after the enactment of the Act. The "Digital Divide Elimination Act of 2000" extends the deadline for contributions of computer technology and equipment for schools to June 30, 2004. Additionally, it redesignates and expands the special rule for computer contributions under section 170(e) of the Internal Revenue Code. The section defines a qualified computer contribution as a charitable donation of computer technology or equipment by a corporation to a qualified organization within 2 years of acquiring the property. The taxpayer must ensure that the property constructed is substantially completed, the original use is by the donor or donee, the property is used mainly within the United States, and not transferred for money or other services, except for shipping. The taxpayer must ensure that the property constructed is substantially completed, the original use is by the donor or donee, the property is used mainly within the United States, and not transferred for money or other services, except for shipping, installation, and transfer costs. In the case of a qualified educational organization, the property must fit productively into the entity's education plan, and its use and disposition must comply with specific provisions. A qualified organization includes qualified educational organizations and public libraries. The tax benefits apply to public libraries, technology centers, and non-profit organizations providing computers to lower-income families in designated areas. Educational organizations must use the donated property in line with their education plan. The term 'qualified educational organization' refers to educational organizations described in subsection (b)(1)(A)(ii) and entities exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) primarily supporting elementary and secondary education. Amendment to the tax code replaces "qualified elementary or secondary educational contribution" with "qualified computer contribution." Effective for taxable years after enactment of the Act.
